Award.AwardTitle: The Lowell Observatory Navajo-Hopi Astronomy Outreach Program: the 2017-2018 School Year
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Lowell Observatory Navajo-Hopi Astronomy Outreach Program is a science enrichment program for Navajo and Hopi elementary school (5th-8th grade) students and their teachers. The program uses astronomy-Â­related activities in order to help teachers inspire students about science. The high school graduation rate of children in the Navajo and Hopi Nations is well below state and national averages; this program aims to inspire Native children to stay in school and to pursue careers in science. The investigators have taken the time to build relationships with the Native communities and to understand cultural differences that might hold children back from engaging in science. For example, several Nations have taboos about looking directly at the Moon or at a solar eclipse. The investigators build partnerships between astronomers and teachers in Native communities with each astronomer making multiple visits to a school to lead activities with the teachers and students. The school groups then visit Lowell Observatory for tours and visit the telescopes for a night of observing.

The investigators plan to develop curriculum based on Project Based Learning and to explore the possibilities of expanding their program. For example, Burt Medicine Bull, a Northern Cheyenne educator, is interested in collaborating with the group. Trying their methods with a different group of students from the Northern Cheyenne Nation will help them determine how easy it will be to export their program. Assessment and evaluation will be managed by an education professor at Northern Arizona University who is an expert at working with Native educational groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Lowell Observatory’s Navajo-Hopi Astronomy Outreach Program is a science enrichment and training program for 5th-8th grade Navajo and Hopi teachers and their students. We partner 5th-8th grade teachers with astronomers who visit the teacher’s classroom and lead hands-on astronomy activities throughout the school year. The goal is to help teachers get kids excited about STEM. The program includes star parties, traditional Native astronomy, field trips to Lowell Observatory, and teacher workshops. 

We are building on our foundation to increase our impact through curriculum development that uses Project Based Learning and cultural connections so that Native students can better see themselves as scientists. Field trips include a poster session that allows students to share their work with astronomers and astronomers to share their research with the students. We have developed and tested a unit on Characteristics of the Planets for 5th grade, and are now working on units for 4th, 6th, and 7th grades.

During the 2017-18 school year, the 22nd year of the Navajo-Hopi Outreach program, we had 8 teacher-astronomer partnerships: 7 on the Navajo Nation and one on the Hopi Nation. Our astronomers conducted about 94 classroom visits and star parties. Four teachers elected to use our 5th grade unit on Characteristics of the Planets, and we developed a technology component for that unit that uses a Sphero robot and tablet to program it to simulate exploration of a distant planetary surface. In addition, a group of Navajo engineers from Raytheon in Tucson came to Lowell to share their stories with students on their field trip. The students heard about careers and how to recover from your mistakes and keep on going. We are working to engage other companies as well. We also developed packets of science activities that kids can do at home to encourage parent participation in their student’s learning and handed these out at star parties.
